contextId.occurrenceNote: This is background information to explain to the reader where the city of Shiloh is located.
contextId.quoteString: which is north of Bethel, east of the road that goes up from Bethel to Shechem, and south of Lebonah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase introduces the beginning of another event in the story line.
This phrase introduces the beginning of another event in the story line.
This is a way to introduce a new person to the story line.

index.name: Introduction of New and Old Participants

contextId.occurrenceNote: Deborah and Barak speak to the kings and leaders as if they were there listening to the song.
contextId.quoteString: Listen, you kings! Pay attention, you leaders

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two negative words “not” and “slow” together emphasize the positive idea to attack quickly. Alternate translation: “Hurry! Attack”
contextId.quoteString: Do not be slow to attack

contextId.occurrenceNote: The two negative words together emphasize a positive idea. Alternate translation: “has everything”
These two phrases mean the same thing and can be combined. Alternate translation: “he did not let Joshua quickly conquer them and drive them out”
contextId.quoteString: did not drive them out quickly and give them into the hand of Joshua

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two words basically mean the same and emphasize how much the Israelites suffered. Alternate translation: “terribly oppressed”
These two words basically have the same meaning repeated to emphasize how important Jephthah had became. You can combine the two words. Alternate translation: “commander”
The words “advice” and “counsel” refer to the same thing and are repeated for emphasis. They can be combined. Alternate translation: “decide what we need to do about this”
contextId.quoteString: give your advice and counsel here

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is understood that the angel of Yahweh is speaking to the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “and said to the people of Israel”
You may want to help your readers by stating where he arrived. Alternate translation: “When he arrived in Seirah”
The word “us” is understood. Alternate translation: “they fought us … fought us”
This can be stated as a complete sentence. Alternate translation: “she grabbed a hammer with her right hand”
contextId.quoteString: her right hand to the workman’s hammer

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “people” or “men” is understood. Alternate translation: “10,000 people remained” or “10,000 men remained”
You can make clear the understood information. Alternate translation: “afraid to go down to attack”
You can make clear the understood information. Alternate translation: “asked for food there in the same way” or “he also asked them for food”
contextId.quoteString: spoke to the people there in the same way

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “her room” is understood from what Samson said to himself. It can be repeated here. Alternate translation: “would not permit him to go into her room”
contextId.quoteString: would not allow him to go in

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “was also gathered to their fathers” means that as the people of that generation died, their souls went to the same place as their ancestors who died before them. It is a polite way of saying they died.
contextId.quoteString: All that generation was also gathered to their fathers

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a polite way to speak about a person having a bowel movement (defecating) or urinating.
This is a polite way of referring to the defeat of his enemies. Alternate translation: “After I have completely defeated the Midian army”
contextId.quoteString: When I come again in peace

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a polite way of referring to people who died in battle. Alternate translation: “had been killed” or “had died in battle”
This is a euphemism. Alternate translation: “had never had sexual relations with a man”
The word “daughter” is a polite way to refer to a young, unmarried woman. Alternate translation: “one of the unmarried women among your relatives”
The phrase “went to bed with” is a polite way of referring to having sex. Alternate translation: “he had sex with her” or “he slept with her”
contextId.quoteString: he went to bed with her

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a euphemism. Alternate translation: “who had not had sexual relations with a man”
contextId.quoteString: who had not known a man by lying with him

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “outrage” describes the “wickedness.” Alternate translation: “outrageous wickedness”
This statement is probably an exaggeration about how few weapons the Israelites had. Alternate translation: “few weapons for battle remained in Israel”
contextId.quoteString: there were no shields or spears seen among forty thousand in Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an exaggeration, a hyperbole, showing the number is very great.
The author uses a hyperbole, an exaggeration, to emphasize that there were very many camels.
contextId.quoteString: Their camels were more & in number than the grains of the sand on the seashore

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “all” is an exaggeration to emphasize that very many worshiped the garment. Alternate translation: “very many people in Israel worshiped the garment”

This could mean: (1) Samson is so thirsty he could literally die. Alternate translation: “But now I will die of thirst and my body will fall into … uncircumcised.” or (2) Samson exaggerates how thirsty he is by asking if he will die of thirst. Alternate translation: “But now will you allow me to become so weak from my thirst that I fall into … uncircumcised?”
contextId.quoteString: But now will I die of thirst and fall into & uncircumcised?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author used a hyperbole, an exaggeration, to emphasize how miserable Sampson felt. Alternate translation: “that he was completely miserable” or “that he was very unhappy”
contextId.quoteString: that he wished he would die

contextId.occurrenceNote: The men use a hyperbole, an exaggeration, to emphasize that it is a very desirable place to live. Alternate translation: “where we will have everything there that we need”
contextId.quoteString: that does not lack anything in the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Israelites are exaggerating. They had already given wives to four hundred of the Benjamites, so the tribe would not be completely destroyed.
contextId.quoteString: There must be an inheritance & is not destroyed from Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “was with” means that Yahweh helped the people of Judah.
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh was with the people of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “escape”
This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “fail to do what I said I would do for you”
Here “forgot” is an idiom that means “they stopped obeying.”
This is an idiom that means he was walking rather than riding a horse or in a chariot.
This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “prayed to Yahweh for help”
The phrase “gave us into” means Yahweh allowed the Israelites to be defeated. Alternate translation: “allowed the Midianites to defeat us”
contextId.quoteString: gave us into the hand of Midian

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “be with you” is an idiom that means Yahweh will help and bless Gideon.
This phrase refers to two people being close to each other. Alternate translation: “really seen the angel of Yahweh”
contextId.quoteString: seen the angel of Yahweh face to face

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “took control of Gideon”
This idiom is a religious oath used for emphasis that what he is about to say is true. Alternate translation: “I promise you that”
This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “they did not attack Israel again”
contextId.quoteString: they did not raise their heads up again

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “when he was very old”
This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “you have opposed” or “you have rebelled against”
This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “And many men died of wounds”
“Evil turn back on their heads” here is an idiom. Alternate translation: “punished the men of Shechem for all the evil they had done”
contextId.quoteString: made all the evil of the men of Shechem turn back on their own heads

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “the curse of Jotham son of Jerub Baal happened to them”
contextId.quoteString: on them came the curse of Jotham son of Jerub Baal

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “made war” is an idiom which means that they attacked Israel and were at war with them. Here “Israel” refers to the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “attacked the people of Israel” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

This is an idiom. Here the phrase “before Yahwheh” means that he repeated his promises as a vow before Yahweh. Alternate translation: “When Jephthah was in Mizpah he repeated all of these promises as a vow before Yahweh”
contextId.quoteString: When he was before Yahweh in Mizpah, Jephthah repeated all the promises he made

contextId.occurrenceNote: Whenever people traveled to the promised land it is referred to as going “up” to the promised land. When the Israelites left Egypt they were on their way to the promised land. Alternate translation: “they left Egypt”
This phrase is an idiom that means to “refuse.” Alternate translation: “refused” or “denied their request”
This is an idiom which means to take control of something. Alternate translation: “take control of” or “take possession of”
This is an idiom which means that the Spirit influenced Jephthah’s decisions. Alternate translation: “the Spirit of Yahweh took control of Jephthah”
contextId.quoteString: the Spirit of Yahweh came on Jephthah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom which means to give something as an offering. Alternate translation: “I will offer it to you” or “I will sacrifice it to you”
This is an idiom. To turn back on a promise means to not do what you have promised to do. Alternate translation: “I must do what I have promised” or “I cannot break my promise”
contextId.quoteString: I cannot turn back on my promise

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means to burn down a house with people inside it. Alternate translation: “We will burn your house down with you still in it”
contextId.quoteString: We will burn your house down over you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom which means to risk one’s life and to rely only on one’s own strength. Jephthah continues to refer to the people of Gilead as himself. Alternate translation: “We risked our lives, relying on our own strength” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: I put my life in my own hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “give away … in marriage” is an idiom which means that he allowed his daughters to get married. Alternate translation: “He had thirty daughters and arranged a marriage for each of them”
contextId.quoteString: He gave away thirty daughters in marriage

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom “bring them in from the outside” means that he had women from other clans marry his sons. Alternate translation: “he arranged for thirty daughters of other men from outside of his clan to marry his sons”
contextId.quoteString: he brought in thirty daughters of other men for his sons, from the outside

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to childbirth. Alternate translation: “bear a son” or “have a baby boy”
This refers to childbirth. Alternate translation: “bear a son” or “have a baby boy”
This refers to childbirth. Alternate translation: “bore a son” or “had a baby boy”

This is an idiom. Samson was demanding his parents to speak to the Philistine woman’s parents about marriage. Alternate translation: “Now arrange for her to become my wife” or “Make the arrangements for me to marry her”
contextId.quoteString: Now get her for me to be my wife

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Samson was demanding his parents to speak to the Philistine woman’s parents about marriage. Alternate translation: “Now arrange for her to be my wife”
The phrase “came on” means that Yahweh’s Spirit influenced Samson. In this case, he made him very strong. Alternate translation: “Yahweh’s Spirit made him very strong”
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh’s Spirit suddenly came on him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that he left his path to do something. Alternate translation: “he left the path”
This means to figure out the meaning of the riddle. Alternate translation: “can figure out its meaning”
The phrase “burn up” means to burn something completely. If a person is “burnt up,” it means that person is burned to death.
Here the word “pressured” means “urged.” Alternate translation: “she kept urging him to tell her”
The phrase “came on” means that Yahweh’s Spirit influenced Samson. In this case, he made him very strong. Alternate translation: “made Samson very strong” or “made Samson very powerful”
This refers to thinking. Alternate translation: “He thought to himself”
The phrase “burned up” means to burn something completely. If a person is “burned up,” it means that person is burned to death.
This means to cause someone to be under someone else’s control. Alternate translation: “give you to the Philistines”
The phrase “came on” means that Yahweh’s Spirit influenced Samson. In this case, he made him very strong. Alternate translation: “made Samson very strong”
This means to die because you have not drank enough and therefore, you do not have enough water in your body.

The phrase “fall into the hands” means to be captured. “Those who are uncircumcised” refers to the Philistines and with the word “uncircumcised” emphasizing that they do not worship Yahweh. Alternate translation: “be captured by those godless Philistines”
contextId.quoteString: fall into the hands of those who are uncircumcised

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that the spring did not dry up but that it remained. The phrase “to this day” refers to the “present” time. Alternate translation: “the spring can still be found at Lehi, even today”
contextId.quoteString: it is at Lehi to this day

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means to learn something. Alternate translation: “to understand” or “to learn”
This is an idiom that refers to where his strength comes from. Alternate translation: “what causes him to be very strong”
The phrase “upon you” means that they are ready to capture him. Alternate translation: “The Philistines are here to capture you”
The phrase “upon you” means that they are there to capture him. Alternate translation: “The Philistines are here to capture you”
This means that they were hiding and waiting for the right moment to attack. Alternate translation: “waiting to attack him”
The phrase “upon you” means that they are there to capture him. Alternate translation: “The Philistines are here to capture you”

Here the author speaks of how Delilah tries to persuade Samson as if she were putting pressure on him to convince him to tell her what she wants to know. Alternate translation: “tried hard to persuade him … kept trying to persuade him”
Here the word “saw” is a idiom that means to realize something. Alternate translation: “Delilah realized” or “Delilah learned”
The phrase “upon you” means that they are ready to capture him. Alternate translation: “The Philistines are here to capture you”
This means that they removed his eyes from his head. Alternate translation: “removed his eyes”
This means to remember him and his situation. Alternate translation: “remember me”

This idiom means that he wants to have one more powerful act against the Philistines to get full revenge for what they did to him. Alternate translation: “with one strike against the Philistine” or “in one powerful act against the Philistines”
contextId.quoteString: in one blow on the Philistines

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means to dedicate something to a specific purpose. Alternate translation: “dedicate”
Here “set apart” means that Micah “dedicated” or “ordained” him. Alternate translation: “Micah dedicated the Levite”
The phrase “on foot” means to walk. Alternate translation: “to scout the land by walking through it”
contextId.quoteString: to scout the land on foot

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that something remains the same. It refers to the “present” time. Alternate translation: “and that is still its name”
“some distance.” This refers a short distance but one that is long enough to be considered as measurable progress.
This means that they continued on their journey. Alternate translation: “continued on their journey” or “continued travelling”
This is an idiom used to make a suggestion. Alternate translation: “I suggest that we”
This means to take a break from their journey and stop somewhere along the route. Alternate translation: “stop at”
This is an idiom used to make a suggestion. Alternate translation: “I suggest that we”
This phrase means for someone to invite them to spend the night in their home. Alternate translation: “invited them to stay in their house for that night”
This phrase refers to someone inviting other people into his house to spend the night there. Alternate translation: “who has invited me to stay in his house”
contextId.quoteString: who will take me into his house

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that he invited the Levite to spend the night in his house. Also, by inviting the Levite he was inviting the man’s concubine and servant as well. Alternate translation: “invited the Levite and his servants to stay in his house” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: brought the Levite into his house

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “making their hearts glad” is an idiom that means to have a good time with someone else. Alternate translation: “they were have a good time together” or “they were enjoying themselves”
contextId.quoteString: they were making their hearts glad

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to morning when it is bright outside. Alternate translation: “the sun was fully risen”

“section by section.” The author uses this graphic description of how the Levite cut up her body into specific pieces to emphasize what he did. “Limbs” refers to a person’s arms and legs. If there is not a similar phrase in your language, this description may be left out of the translation.
This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “kill them” or “execute them”
Here “strengthened” is an idiom that means they encouraged each other.
This is an idiom that means these were particularly good soldiers. Alternate translation: “well-trained soldier”
This is an idiom that means they intentionally retreated. Alternate translation: “had allowed Benjamin to move forward”
This is an idiom that means they trusted their men.
contextId.quoteString: they were counting on the men

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means it happened to them. Alternate translation: “happened to them”
This idiom refers to everything that they found as they went toward the city. Alternate translation: “they came to”
“They refused to stop doing evil things and being stubborn.” This can be stated in positive form. Alternate translation: “They continued doing evil things and being stubborn”
contextId.quoteString: They refused to give up any of their evil practices or their stubborn ways

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be written as a positive statement. Alternate translation: “We have everything we need”
This contrast probably refers to rich people and poor people. Alternate translation: “you rich people who ride on white donkeys … you poor people who walk along the road”
contextId.quoteString: you who ride on white donkeys & you who walk along the road

contextId.occurrenceNote: This emphasizes that it would be for his entire life. Alternate translation: “all his life”
contextId.quoteString: from the time he is in your womb until the day of his death

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the land as a whole. Alternate translation: “from all the eleven tribes”
The Canaanites troubling the Israelites is spoken of as if the Canaanites would be thorns in the side of the Israelites. Alternate translation: “cause you trouble”
The Israelites worshiping the Canaanite gods is spoken of as if the false gods were a hunter’s trap that catches an animal and causes it harm.
contextId.quoteString: their gods will become a trap for you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The sight of Yahweh represents Yahweh’s judgment or evaluation. Alternate translation: “what was evil in Yahweh’s judgment” or “what Yahweh considered to be evil”
contextId.quoteString: what was evil in the sight of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Israelites starting to worship false gods is spoken of as if the Israelites walked and went after the false gods.
The anger of Yahweh is described as burning like a fire. Alternate translation: “Yahweh became very angry with the people of Israel”
contextId.quoteString: The anger of Yahweh burned against Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh allowing the enemies to take the Israelites as slaves is spoken of as if he sold them into slavery. The phrase “who were held by” can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “He allowed their enemies to conquer them and take them as slaves, and they could no longer resist their powerful enemies” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: He sold them as slaves who were held by the strength of their enemies around them, so they could no longer defend themselves against their enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh appointing persons to be judges is spoken of as if he were raising or lifting the persons up.
Yahweh appointing persons to be judges is spoken of as if he raised or lifted up the persons.
The people no longer obeying Yahweh is spoken of as if they would physically turn away from Yahweh.
The Israelites worshiping other gods is spoken of as if they were walking and going after other gods. Alternate translation: “They would serve and worship other gods”
contextId.quoteString: They would go after other gods to serve them and worship them

contextId.occurrenceNote: How Yahweh wants people to live or behave is spoken of as if it were a way or road. A person obeying Yahweh is spoken of as if they were walking in his way.
contextId.quoteString: they will keep the way of Yahweh and walk in it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh becoming very angry is spoken of as if his anger were something that could be set on fire. Alternate translation: “Yahweh became very angry”
contextId.quoteString: the anger of Yahweh was set on fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: Allowing the people of Israel to be conquered is spoken of as if Yahweh sold them to Cushan-Rishathaim. Alternate translation: “allowed Cushan-Rishathaim and his army to defeat them”
contextId.quoteString: sold them into the hand of Cushan-Rishathaim

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh appointing someone to do a special work for him is spoken of as if Yahweh raised or lifted up the person.
Yahweh appointing someone to do a special service for him is spoken of as if he raised or lifted up the person.
Yahweh helping the Israelites to defeat their enemies is spoken of as if Yahweh were a warrior who would fight and defeat their enemies.
contextId.quoteString: for Yahweh is about to defeat your enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: The choice Barak makes is spoken of as if Barak were choosing a road on which to travel. And, “honor” is spoken of as if it were a destination to which one travels. Alternate translation: “no one will honor you for what you do”
contextId.quoteString: the road on which you are going will not lead to your honor

contextId.occurrenceNote: God causing the Israelites to defeat Jabin and his army is spoken of as is God himself defeated Jabin as the people of Israel watched.
contextId.quoteString: God defeated Jabin, the king of Canaan, before the people of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the time when the Israelites left Edom to start conquering the people in Canaan. Yahweh empowering his people to defeat the people of Canaan is spoken of as if he were a warrior leading the Israelite army.
contextId.quoteString: when you went out from Seir, when you marched from Edom

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) this is poetic language that emphasizes Yahweh’s power by describing it as causing earthquakes and storms or (2) the people of Canaan being terrified as the Israelites were about to attack them is spoken of as if the earth and sky were shaking.
contextId.quoteString: the earth shook, and the skies also trembled; also the clouds poured down water

contextId.occurrenceNote: Deborah speaks of becoming a leader in Israel as if she were a mother taking care of young children. Alternate translation: “I, Deborah, began to lead—I took care of the Israelites as a mother takes care of her children”
contextId.quoteString: I, Deborah, arose—arose as a mother in Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Ephraim living in the land where the descendants of Amalek originally lived is spoken of as if the people of Ephraim were planted and their roots grew into the land. Alternate translation: “from Ephraim, that land where the descendants of Amalek once lived”
contextId.quoteString: from Ephraim, whose root is in Amalek

contextId.occurrenceNote: Moses speaks of Egypt as if it were a house where people keep slaves. Alternate translation: “the place where you were slaves”
This speaks of worshiping a false god as if it were prostitution. Alternate translation: “the Israelites sinned against Yahweh by worshiping the ephod there”
contextId.quoteString: all Israel prostituted themselves by worshiping it there

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Gideon and his family being tempted to worship the ephod as if the ephod were a hunter’s snare that would trap them. Alternate translation: “It became a temptation for Gideon and his family” or “Gideon and his family sinned by worshiping it”
contextId.quoteString: It became a trap for Gideon and for those in his house

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people rejecting Yahweh is spoken of as if they physically turned away from him. Alternate translation: “they stopped worshiping Yahwheh”
This speaks of worshiping false gods as if it were prostitution. Alternate translation: “they sinned against Yahweh by worshiping the Baals”
contextId.quoteString: prostituted themselves by worshiping the Baals

contextId.occurrenceNote: To sway is to move back and forth. Trees sway when the wind blows them. Here this is a metaphor for ruling over people. Jotham is also using irony, saying that the work of any ruler will be useless because the “trees,” the people, will not obey anyone who rules them. Alternate translation: “rule over”
Jotham is speaking a curse. He speaks of Abimelech destroying the people of Shechem as if he would burn them with fire.
contextId.quoteString: let fire come out from Abimelech and burn up the men of Shechem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jotham is speaking a curse. He speaks of the people of Shechem and Beth Millo destroying Abimelech as if they would burn him with fire.
contextId.quoteString: Let fire come out from the men of Shechem and Beth Millo, to burn up Abimelech

contextId.occurrenceNote: Becoming angry is spoken of as if a fire were starting. Alternate translation: “he became very angry”
This speaks of the people of the city becoming upset as if they were liquid in a pot moving around. Alternate translation: “they are persuading the people of the city to rebel against you”
contextId.quoteString: they are stirring up the city against you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of evil as if it were an object that a person could add to and make bigger. Alternate translation: “continued doing what Yahweh said was evil”
contextId.quoteString: added to the evil they had done in the sight of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The sight of Yahweh represents Yahweh’s judgment or evaluation. Alternate translation: “according to Yahweh”
No longer obeying and worshiping Yahweh is spoken of as if the people left Yahweh and went somewhere else.
Yahweh becoming angry is spoken of as if anger were a burning fire. Alternate translation: “Yahweh was very angry at Israel”
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh burned with anger toward Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh allowing the Philistines and the Ammonites to defeat the Israelites is spoken of as if he sold the Israelites to them.
contextId.quoteString: he sold them into the hand of the Philistines and into the hand of the Ammonites

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people no longer obeying and worshiping Yahweh is spoken of as if they left Yahweh and went somewhere else.
The people no longer obeying and worshiping Yahweh is spoken of as if they left Yahweh and went somewhere else.
Here Jephthah speaks of his great sorrow as something that crushes him. Alternate translation: “You have caused me great sorrow” or “You have filled me with sorrow”
contextId.quoteString: You have crushed me with sorrow

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Jephthah talks about his great distress and trouble as if it were pain. Alternate translation: “you have become someone who troubles me” or “you cause me great distress”
contextId.quoteString: you have become one who causes me pain

contextId.occurrenceNote: Something that Yahweh has stated is unfit to eat is spoken of as if it were physically unclean.
Something that Yahweh has stated is unfit to eat is spoken of as if it were physically unclean.
contextId.quoteString: any food that the law declares to be unclean

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the way Yahweh’s Spirit influences Samson is compared to the way a spoon stirs food in a pot. Alternate translation: “Yahweh’s Spirit began to influence Samson”
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh’s Spirit began to stir him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Samson compares their using his wife to get the answer to someone using another person’s heifer to plow his field. Alternate translation: “If you had not used my wife”
contextId.quoteString: If you had not plowed with my heifer

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the author speak of Samson being under the rulers’ control as if he were something grasped tightly by their hands. Alternate translation: “put him under our control”
The eyes represent seeing, and seeing represents thoughts or judgment. Alternate translation: “each person did what he decided was right” or “each person did what he judged to be right”
contextId.quoteString: everyone did what was right in his own eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to a time later on when the people of Dan would be captured by their enemies. Here the land being conquered is spoken of as if it were a prisoner taken captive by an enemy. Alternate translation: “until the day that their enemies conquered their land” or “until the day that their enemies took them captive”
contextId.quoteString: until the day of the land’s captivity

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the man looked up and paid attention to what was around him. Alternate translation: “He looked up”
Here the author speaks of “agreeing” as if it were “listening.” Alternate translation: “the men would not accept his offer”
contextId.quoteString: the men would not listen to him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here immanent disaster is spoken of as if it was standing very close by them. Alternate translation: “they would soon be completely defeated”
The completed destruction of the Benjamites is spoken of as if the Israelites stomped on their bodies. Alternate translation: “they completely destroyed them”
This speaks of the tribe of Benjamin as if it were Israel’s brother to show their closeness to the tribe. Alternate translation: “the surviving Benjamites”

The destruction of the tribe of Benjamin is spoken of as if it had been cut off from Israel by a knife. This was an exaggeration because 600 men were still left. However, the women of Benjamin had been killed, so the future of the tribe was in question. Alternate translation: “one tribe has been removed” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: one tribe has been cut off from Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The eyes represent seeing, and seeing represents thoughts or judgment. Alternate translation: “what he judged to be right” or “what he considered to be right”
contextId.quoteString: what was right in his own eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Forcing these kings to eat scraps of food represents all the ways that Adoni-Bezek humiliated these kings. Here “gathering” food represents eating it. Alternate translation: “ate scraps of food from under my table”
contextId.quoteString: gathered their food from under my table

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “city” represents the people. Alternate translation: “the people who lived in Jerusalem and defeated them”
contextId.quoteString: the city of Jerusalem and took it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “it” refers to the city which represents the people of the city. Alternate translation: “They attacked the people of the city”
Here “Kiriath Sepher” represents the people. Alternate translation: “Whoever attacks and defeats the people of Kiriath Sepher and takes their city”
contextId.quoteString: Whoever attacks Kiriath Sepher and takes it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” represents descendants. Manasseh and Ephraim were sons of Joseph, and the “house of Joseph” can refer to the descendants of Manasseh and Ephraim. Alternate translation: “The descendants of Manasseh and Ephraim” or “The men of the tribes of Manasseh and Ephraim”
Here “Bethel” represents the people who live in Bethel.
Here “city” represents the people. Alternate translation: “they attacked the people of the city”
Here “Israel” represents the people. Alternate translation: “When the people of Israel became stronger”
Here “Ephraim” the men or the soldiers of the tribe of Ephraim.
Here “Zebulun” represents the men or the soldiers of the tribe of Zebulun.
Here “Zebulun” represents the people of the tribe of Zebulun.
Here “Asher” represents the men or the soldiers of the tribe of Asher.

Here “house” represents descendants. Manasseh and Ephraim were sons of Joseph, and the “house of Joseph” can refer to the descendants of Manasseh and Ephraim. Alternate translation: “the descendants of Manasseh and Ephraim” or “the men of the tribes of Manasseh and Ephraim”
Here “voice” represents what Yahweh said. Alternate translation: “you have not obeyed my commands”
contextId.quoteString: you have not listened to my voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” represents Yahweh’s power. Alternate translation: “Yahweh helped their enemies defeat them”
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh’s hand was against them to defeat them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” refers to power. Alternate translation: “from the power of the enemies”
contextId.quoteString: out of the hand of those

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” refers to power of the enemies to hurt Israel. Alternate translation: “the power of their enemies”
The sound made by a person who suffers is used to describe the pain of the Israelites as they suffer. Alternate translation: “as they suffered”
Here “nation” represents the people. Alternate translation: “these people have broken” or “the Israelites have broken”
Here “nations” represents the people groups that lived in Canaan before the Israelites.

Here “hand” is a metonym for power, and “Joshua” represents himself and his army. Alternate translation: “into the power of Joshua and his army” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
Here “hand” is a metonym that represents power or control. Also, “Cushan-Rishathaim” is a synechdoche that represents himself and his army. (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
Here “hand” is a metonym for army. Alternate translation: “The army of Othniel”
“The land” is used to refer to the people who lived in the land. Alternate translation: “The people lived peacefully”
Here “strength” represents the Israelite army.
Here “land” represents the people. Alternate translation: “the Israelites lived peacefully”
The word “danger” refers to enemies that tried to harm the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “He also delivered the people of Israel from their enemies”
contextId.quoteString: He also delivered Israel from danger

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” refers to Jabin’s power over Israel. Yahweh’s decision to give Jabin power over them is spoken of as if Yahweh had sold them to Jabin. Alternate translation: “Yahweh allowed them to be defeated by the power of Jabin king of Canaan” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh sold them into the hand of Jabin king of Canaan

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” refers to her power to kill him. Alternate translation: “for Yahweh will cause a woman to defeat Sisera”
contextId.quoteString: for Yahweh will sell Sisera into the hand of a woman

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “chariots” represents the soldiers who drove the chariots.
contextId.quoteString: Sisera called out all his chariots

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “chariots” is a metonym for the soldiers driving the chariots. Alternate translation: “all the men driving chariots”
Here “face” refers Yahweh’s presence. Alternate translation: “in the presence of Yahweh”

The word “heart” represents a person’s emotions. The phrase “My heart goes out to” is a way of saying that Deborah feels gratitude or appreciation. Alternate translation: “I appreciate the commanders of Israel” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: My heart goes out to the commanders of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Military leaders are described by the staff, a symbol of their authority. Alternate translation: “military leaders from Zebulun”
contextId.quoteString: from Zebulun those who carry an officer’s staff

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Issachar” refers to the tribe of Issachar. Alternate translation: “the tribe of Issachar was with Barak”

Here “heart” represents thoughts. The people discussing with each other but being unable to decide what they should do is spoken of as if they were searching their heart. Alternate translation: “there was a lot of discussing about what they should do” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: there were great searchings of heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Gilead” the men from Gilead who should have gone to fight in battle. Alternate translation: “The men of Gilead stayed”
Here “Dan” represents the men from Dan who should have gone to fight in battle. Alternate translation: “the men of Dan, why did they”
Here “Asher” represents the men who should have gone to fight in battle. Alternate translation: “The men of Asher remained”
Here “Meroz” represents the people who lived there. Alternate translation: “Curse the people of Meroz”
Both of these represent Sisera. Alternate translation: “taken Sisera … Why has he”
contextId.quoteString: taken his chariot & Why have the hoofbeats of the horses that pull his chariots

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the land” represents the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “and the people of Israel lived peacefully”
Here “Midian” represents the people of Midian. Also, “hand” represents control. Alternate translation: “the control of the people of Midian” or “the control of the Midianites”
Here “the power of Midian” refers to the people of Midian. Alternate translation: “The people of Midian were more powerful than the people of Israel and they oppressed them”
contextId.quoteString: The power of Midian oppressed Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Midian” represents the people of Midian.
Here “Midian” represents the people of Midian. Alternate translation: “because of the Midianites”
In this phrase “hand” represents power or control.
Here “my voice” represents what Yahweh commanded. Alternate translation: “obeyed my command” or “obeyed me”
Here “hand” represents power or control.
Here “Midian” represents the people of Midian. Alternate translation: “of the Midianites”
Here “hand” represents power or control.
Here “Midian” represents the people of Midian. Alternate translation: “of the Midianites”
These all represent the people of each tribe. Alternate translation: “to the tribes of Asher, Zebulun, and Naphtali”
Here “Midian” represents the Midianite army. Alternate translation: “The Midianite army set up their camp to the north of the Israelite army”
contextId.quoteString: The camp of Midian was to their north

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “power” represents the people themselves. Alternate translation: “We have saved ourselves without God’s help”
contextId.quoteString: Our own power has saved us

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “number” represents the army. The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “there, I will show you who to send home so the army will have less men” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: I will make their number smaller for you there

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “camp” refers to the whole Midianite army. The word “victory” is an abstract noun that can be translated as a verb or an adjective. Alternate translation: “Attack the Midianites at their camp, for I am going to help you defeat them” or “Attack the Midianites at their camp, for I am going to cause you to be victorious over them” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: Attack the camp, for I am going to give you victory over it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the sword of Gideon” refers to Gideon’s army attacking. Alternate translation: “The loaf of barley bread in your dream must be the army of Gideon”
contextId.quoteString: This is nothing other than the sword of Gideon

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sword” refers to their fighting. Alternate translation: “We fight for Yahweh and for Gideon”
contextId.quoteString: The sword of Yahweh and of Gideon

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sword” refers to their attack with the use of the sword. Alternate translation: “Yahweh caused every Midianite man to fight against his fellow soldiers”
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh set every Midianite man’s sword against his comrades

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Midian” represents the Midianite army.
This is the name of one of Gideon’s ancestors. Gideon used his name to refer to Abiezer’s descendants and their land. (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
Here “hand” represents power or control.

Here drawing the sword represents using the sword in battle. This could mean: (1) this phrase refers to soldiers who use swords in battle. Alternate translation: “swordsmen” or “men who fought with swords” or (2) this phrase refers to any soldiers. Alternate translation: “soldiers”
Here “hand” represents the power of Midian over Israel. Alternate translation: “from the power of Midian” or “from Midian”
contextId.quoteString: out of the hand of Midian

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Midian” represents the people of Midian. Alternate translation: “of the Midianites”
Here “his house” represents Gideon’s family. Alternate translation: “for his family”
Here “land” represents the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “So the Israelites lived peacefully”
Here “hand” represents power or control. Alternate translation: “from the power of all their enemies” or “from all their enemies”
contextId.quoteString: from the hand of all their enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the house of” represents a person’s family. Alternate translation: “the family of Jerub Baal”
Here “your bone and your flesh” represents being someone’s relative. Alternate translation: “I am a member of your family”
contextId.quoteString: I am your bone and your flesh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” represents a temple.
This word for “wealth” is a metonym for the olives that come from the tree. People ate olives as food and crushed them to make oil for lamps. Alternate translation: “oil”
Here “house” represents Gideon’s family.
Here “hand” represents power or control. Alternate translation: “from the power of the Midianites” or “from the Midianites”
contextId.quoteString: out of the hand of Midian

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” represents family. Alternate translation: “my father’s family”
Here “house” refers to family. Alternate translation: “his family”
Here “house” represents a temple.
Here “city” represents the people of the city.
Here “city” represents the people. Alternate translation: “against the people of Shechem”
Here this represents a temple.
Here “Israel” represents the people of Israel.
Here “Israel” represents the people of Israel.
Here “hand” represents power or control.
“Judah” and “Benjamin” refer to the people belonging to those tribes. Alternate translation: “the people of the tribe of Judah … the people of the tribe of Benjamin”
The “house” refers to the people of the tribe of Ephraim. Alternate translation: “the people of the tribe of Ephraim”
“Israel” refers to the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “so that the people of Israel suffered much”
contextId.quoteString: so that Israel was greatly distressed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “power” represents the Amalekites and the Maonites. Alternate translation: “from them”
Here Israel refers to the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “And Yahweh did not want the people of Israel to suffer any longer”
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh could bear Israel’s misery no longer

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” refers to people living in the house. Alternate translation: “my family”
Here “hand” refers to power to defeat in battle. Alternate translation: “gave Israel power over Sihon and all his people”
contextId.quoteString: gave Sihon and all his people into the hand of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: These men owned seventy donkeys, which they did ride. Here the word “rode” is used instead of “owned.” Alternate translation: “They owned seventy donkeys”
Here “hand” refers to power to gain victory in battle. Alternate translation: “he allowed the Philistines to defeat them” or “he allowed them to be oppressed by the Philistines”
contextId.quoteString: he gave them into the hand of the Philistines

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “head” refers to his hair. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “No one should ever cut his hair” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: No razor will be used upon his head

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “womb” refers to the time before the child is born. Alternate translation: “from before he is born”
Here the angel refers to any food that grow on a vine as “coming” from the vine. Alternate translation: “anything that grows on a vine”
contextId.quoteString: anything that comes from the vines

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) this refers to the actual house. Alternate translation: “the house your father and his family live in” or (2) “house” refers to the people who live in it. Alternate translation: “your family”
Here “hands” refers to power. Alternate translation: “the Philistine’s control”
Here “from my mother’s womb” refers to when he was born. This means that he has been a Nazirite since he was born. Alternate translation: “my entire life”
Here the word “house” refers to his family. Alternate translation: “all of his father’s family”
contextId.quoteString: all the house of his father

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “father” is here used in the sense of an advisor, and not to a literal father. Alternate translation: “an advisor and a priest”
Here living in Micah’s house is spoken of as “being” in his house. Alternate translation: “lived in Micah’s house”
The phrase “the whole number” refers to all of the men in the tribe. Alternate translation: “from among all of the men in their tribe”
contextId.quoteString: from the whole number of their tribe

contextId.occurrenceNote: They recognized the man by the sound of his voice. Here “speech” refers to his “voice.” Alternate translation: “they heard the young Levite talking, and they recognized his voice”
contextId.quoteString: they recognized the speech of the young Levite

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah did not make his gods, rather the craftsman made them. Alternate translation: “the gods which I had made for me” or “the gods which a craftsman made for me”

The phrase “us hear you say” refers to the Danites hearing Micah speaking about what had happened, but it also includes if they are told by others that Micah had spoken about what had happened. Alternate translation: “let us find out that you have said anything” or “say anything about this”
contextId.quoteString: let us hear you say anything

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah did not make his gods, rather a craftsman made them for him. Also, If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “the things that had been made for Micah” or “Micah’s things” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
Micah did not make his gods, rather the craftsman made them for him. Alternate translation: “that had been made for him” or “that his craftsman made for him”

The father-in-law is suggesting that he strengthen himself by eating. He is also asking him to wait until the afternoon to leave. This can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “Eat some food so you will be strong enough to travel, and wait until afternoon to leave” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Strengthen yourself, and wait until the afternoon

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “voice” refers to the message that they spoke. Alternate translation: “what their brother said”
Here “Israel” refers to the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “the Israelites”
Here “the city” refers to the people in that city. Alternate translation: “everyone who was in the city”
Both of these questions mean the same thing. These two statements can be combined. Alternate translation: “Why is it taking Sisera so long to arrive home”
contextId.quoteString: Why has it taken his chariot so long to come? Why have the hoofbeats of the horses that pull his chariots been delayed?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases have the same meaning.

Both of these questions means the same thing. Gaal refers to Abimelech as “Shechem” because Abimelech’s mother was from Shechem. Alternate translation: “We should not serve Abimelech, that is, Shechem!”
contextId.quoteString: Who is Abimelech, and who is Shechem, that we should serve him?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author basically said the same thing twice for emphasis. These can be combined. Alternate translation: “They completely stopped worshiping Yahweh”
contextId.quoteString: They abandoned Yahweh and no longer worshiped him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jephthah said basically the same thing twice to emphasize that he was very sad”
contextId.quoteString: You have crushed me with sorrow & you have become one who causes me pain

contextId.occurrenceNote: Manoah’s wife said basically the same thing twice for emphasis. These two statements can be combined. Alternate translation: “He would not have told us what he wanted us to do”
contextId.quoteString: He would not have shown us all these things, nor at this time would he have let us hear such things

contextId.occurrenceNote: Samson’s wife basically said the same thing twice for emphasis. Alternate translation: “You do not really love me at all”
contextId.quoteString: All you do is hate me! You do not love me

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrase mean basically the same thing and emphasize that Samson became strong again. These two statements can be combined. Alternate translation: “he became strong again” or “he was revived”
contextId.quoteString: his strength returned and he revived

contextId.occurrenceNote: Deceiving and lying mean the same thing and are stated to emphasize how angry Delilah felt. Alternate translation: “You have greatly deceived me!”
contextId.quoteString: This is how you have deceived me and told me lies.

contextId.occurrenceNote: Deceiving and lying mean the same thing and are stated to emphasize how angry Delilah felt. Alternate translation: “you have greatly deceived me”
contextId.quoteString: you have deceived me and told me lies

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two clauses say basically the same thing twice for emphasis. They can be combined. The words “none … go” and “none … return” emphasizes how the people will continue to stay there. They can be stated in positive form. Alternate translation: “We will all stay here” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-litotes]])
contextId.quoteString: None of us will go to his tent & none of us will return to his house

contextId.occurrenceNote: This probably refers to earthquakes and gives the impression that the mountains quaked because they were very afraid of Yahweh. Alternate translation: “The mountains trembled in fear” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Yahweh helping the Israelite to defeat Sisera and his army is spoken of as if the stars themselves fought against Sisera and his army. This may refer to Yahweh using natural elements, specifically rain storms, to defeat Sisera.
contextId.quoteString: From heaven the stars fought, from their paths across the heavens they fought against Sisera

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jotham continues describing the trees as doing things that humans do. (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: the fig tree said to them

contextId.occurrenceNote: In this parable, Jotham describes the trees and the vine as doing things that humans do.
contextId.quoteString: The trees said to the vine

contextId.occurrenceNote: Samson speaks about his strength as if it were a person who could leave him. Alternate translation: “I will not be strong any more”
Here Samson’s strength is described as if it were a person who could leave him. Alternate translation: “his strength was gone” or “he was no longer strong”
This speaks about fighting as if it were a person who could overtake someone. Alternate translation: “But the soldiers of Israel caught up to them” or “But they were not able to escape the fighting”
This question is asked to cause the people of Israel to realize they have disobeyed Yahweh and will suffer because of it. Alternate translation: “You have done a terrible thing.”
contextId.quoteString: What is this that you have done?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Deborah asks this question to remind Barak that they fight on the side of Yahweh. Alternate translation: “Remember, Yahweh is leading you.”

This question is asked to express anger because the people of the tribe of Dan would not fight for Israel. Alternate translation: “the men of Dan should not have remained on their ships!” or “the people of the tribe of Dan did not help us in the battle. Instead they were wandering around on the sea in ships!” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Dan, why did he wander about on ships?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The women use a question to emphasize that they believe this is what certainly happened. Alternate translation: “They must have so much plunder that it is taking a long time to divide it. They have … plunder.”
contextId.quoteString: Have they not found and divided up the plunder—a womb & plunder?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The women use a question to emphasize that they believe this is what certainly happened. Alternate translation: “There must be a womb, two wombs for every man … of those who plunder.”
contextId.quoteString: a womb, two wombs for every man & of those who plunder?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Gideon uses a question to challenge the stranger’s statement that Yahweh was with him. Also, the direct quotation can be stated as an indirect quotation. Alternate translation: “We have not seen any wonderful deeds like the ones our fathers told us about when Yahweh brought them up from Egypt.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-quotations]])
contextId.quoteString: Where are all his wonderful deeds that our fathers told us about, when they said, ‘Did not Yahweh bring us up from Egypt?’

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses a question to ensure Gideon that he is sending him. Here “sent” means Yahweh has appointed Gideon with a specific task. Alternate translation: “I, Yahweh, am sending you!”
Gideon uses a question to emphasize that he does not think he can rescue the Israelites. Alternate translation: “I cannot possibly rescue the Israelites!”
Joash uses a question to emphasize that a human should not have to defend a god. Alternate translation: “You should not have to defend Baal.”
contextId.quoteString: Will you plead the case for Baal?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Joash uses a question to emphasize that a human should not have to rescue a god. Alternate translation: “You should not have to save Baal.”

The people of the tribe of Ephraim were rebuking Gideon with this rhetorical question for not including them in his army. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You have not treated us fairly.”
contextId.quoteString: What is this you have done to us?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Gideon uses this question to honor the people of Ephraim. Alternate translation: “I have done very little compared with what you have done!”
contextId.quoteString: What have I done now compared to you?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Gideon was calming the people of Ephraim with this rhetorical question. Alternate translation: “Certainly the grapes you people of Ephraim gleaned are better than what we the descendants of Abiezer gathered from the whole harvest!”
contextId.quoteString: Are not the gleanings of Ephraim’s grapes better than the full grape harvest of Abiezer?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Gideon and his army defeating the Medianites is spoken of as if it were a grape harvest. The people of Ephraim killing Oreb and Zeeb at the end of the battle is spoken of as if they were gleaning grapes at the end of the harvest. Alternate translation: “What you people of Ephraim did at the end of the battle is more important than what we descendants of Abiezer did at the beginning.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Are not the gleanings of Ephraim’s grapes better than the full grape harvest of Abiezer?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Gideon uses this question to honor the people of Ephraim. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “What you have done is more important than what I have done.”
contextId.quoteString: What have I accomplished compared to you?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The leaders use a question to emphasize that the Israelites have not yet captured Zebah and Zalumnna. Alternate translation: “You have not captured Zebah and Zalmunna yet.”
contextId.quoteString: Are the hands of Zebah and Zalmunna now in your hand?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The leaders use a question to emphasize that they have no reason to give bread to the Israelites. Alternate translation: “We see no reason to give bread to your army.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Why should we give bread to your army?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Gideon quotes the people of Succoth as using a question to mock him. Alternate translation: “You have not yet conquered Zebah and Zalmunna.”
contextId.quoteString: Have you already conquered Zebah and Zalmunna?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The olive tree is asking this question to refuse to be king. This question can be expressed as a statement. Alternate translation: “I will not give up my abundance … over the other trees.”
contextId.quoteString: Should I give up my abundance & over the other trees?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The fig tree is asking this question to refuse to be king. This question can be expressed as a statement. Alternate translation: “I will not give up my sweetness … over the other trees.”
contextId.quoteString: Should I give up my sweetness & over the other trees?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The vine is asking this question to refuse to be king. This question can be expressed as a statement. Alternate translation: “I will not give up my new wine … over the other trees.”
contextId.quoteString: Should I give up my new wine & over the other trees?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Gaal uses a question to emphasize that the people of Shechem should not serve Abimelech. Alternate translation: “We should not serve Abimelech!”
contextId.quoteString: Who is Abimelech, and who is Shechem, that we should serve him?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Gaal uses a question to emphasize that the people of Shechem should not serve Abimelech. Alternate translation: “He is just the son of Jerub Baal, and Zebul is just his officer.”
contextId.quoteString: Is he not the son of Jerub Baal? Is Zebul not his officer?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Gaal uses a question to emphasize that the people of Shechem should not serve Abimelech. Alternate translation: “We should not serve Abimelech!”
Zebul is scolding Gaal with this rhetorical question. Alternate translation: “You are not speaking proudly now, you” or “You are not proud now, you”
contextId.quoteString: Where are your proud words now, you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Zebul is quoting Gaal’s boast back to Gaal. This can be translated as a statement and as an indirect quote. Alternate translation: “you who said that we should not serve Abimelech.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-quotations]])
contextId.quoteString: you who said, ‘Who is Abimelech that we should serve him?’

contextId.occurrenceNote: Zebul is challenging Gaal with this rhetorical question. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Here are the men that you despised.”
contextId.quoteString: Are these not the men you despised?

contextId.occurrenceNote: God is rebuking the people of Israel for their worship of other gods. The rhetorical question that begins with the words “Did I not deliver you” in verse 11 ends here. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “I am the one who delivered you … and also from the Sidonians.”

Jephthah is rebuking the king of the Ammonites with this rhetorical question. The word “their” refers to the Israel. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “therefore, you should not take possession of their land.”
contextId.quoteString: should you now take possession of their land?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jephthah is rebuking the king of the Ammonites with a rhetorical question. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You should only take over the land that Chemosh, your god, gives you.”
contextId.quoteString: Will you not take over the land that Chemosh, your god, gives you?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jephthah is rebuking the king of the Ammonites with a rhetorical question. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You are not better than Balak son of Zippor, who was king of Moab.”
contextId.quoteString: Now are you really better than Balak son of Zippor, king of Moab?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jephthah is rebuking the king of the Ammonites with a rhetorical question. This question can be translated with a statement. Alternate translation: “Yet he did not dare to have an argument with Israel.”
contextId.quoteString: Did he dare to have an argument with Israel?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jephthah is rebuking the king of the Ammonites with a rhetorical question. This question can be translated with a statement. Alternate translation: “Nor did he ever wage war against them.”
contextId.quoteString: Did he ever wage war against them?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jephthah is rebuking the king of the Ammonites with a rhetorical question. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “you should have taken them back during that time.” or “now it is too late; you should have taken them back long ago.”
contextId.quoteString: why then did you not take them back during that time?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The angel asks this question as a rebuke. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You should not ask me what my name is.”
contextId.quoteString: Why do you ask my name?

contextId.occurrenceNote: They ask this question to suggest that they could find Samson a wife among their own people. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Surely there are women among your people whom you could marry.”
contextId.quoteString: Is there not a woman among the daughters of your relatives, or among all our people?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This question is asked to rebuke Samson. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express the idea behind this question as a statement. you could make explicit the reason his parents do not want him to marry a Philistine. Alternate translation: “You really should not marry a Philistine woman because the Philistine people do not worship Yahweh.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Are you going to take a wife from the uncircumcised Philistines?

contextId.occurrenceNote: They ask her this question to accuse her of doing evil. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You have brought us here to make us poor!”
contextId.quoteString: Did you invite us here in order to make us poor?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Samson was rebuking her for demanding that he tell her the answer. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “I have not even told my father or mother. I will not tell you.” or “you should not demand that I tell you, since I have not even told my parents, and they are closer to me than you are.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: if I have not told my father or my mother, should I tell you?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the answer to the riddle. It may be written as a statement instead of as questions. If necessary it could be made clear how this relates to the riddle by adding more information. Alternate translation: “Honey is sweet and a lion is strong.” or “Honey is sweet and it came out of a lion.” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: What is sweeter than honey? What is stronger than a lion?

contextId.occurrenceNote: He asks this question to imply that Samson should agree with him. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “I hope you agree.”

The men of Judah ask Samson these questions to rebuke him. This questions may be written as a statements. Alternate translation: “You know that the Philistines are rulers over us but you act like they are not. What you have done has caused us great harm.”
contextId.quoteString: Do you not know that the Philistines are rulers over us? What is this you have done to us?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Delilah asks this question to say that if Samson really loved her he would tell her his secrets. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “When you say ‘I love you,’ you are lying because you do not share your secrets with me.”
contextId.quoteString: How can you say, ‘I love you,’ when you do not share your secrets with me?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This rhetorical question is asked sarcastically and means that they should be doing the opposite. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You should be acting now!” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublenegatives]])

The five men asked this question to suggest and encourage the men that they should steal the idols. This can be written as a statement, and the implied information may be given in a parenthetical phrase. Alternate translation: “these houses contain an ephod, … metal figure. (They were suggesting that the men steal these things.) Decide … will do” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: in these houses there are an ephod, & metal figure? Decide & will do

contextId.occurrenceNote: They ask this as a rhetorical question to imply that it is true. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “It is better for you to be priest for a tribe and a clan in Israel than for just the house of one man.”
contextId.quoteString: Is it better for you to be priest for the house of one man & a clan in Israel?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This question is a rebuke. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You should not have called your men together to chase us.”
contextId.quoteString: Why have you been called together?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah asks this question to emphasize that he no longer has the things that are important to him. Alternate translation: “I have nothing left.” or “You have taken everything that is important to me.”
contextId.quoteString: What else do I have left?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Micah asks this question to emphasize that the Danites definitely know what is bothering him. Alternate translation: “You know that I am greatly distressed!’” or “You know how much I am bothered by what you have done to me!’”
contextId.quoteString: How can you ask me, ‘What is bothering you?’

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Israel used this rhetorical question to express their deep sadness. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Oh Yahweh, we are so sad that one of the tribes of Israel has been completely destroyed.”
contextId.quoteString: Why, Yahweh, God of Israel, has this happened to Israel, that one of our tribes should be missing today?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people betraying Yahweh and worshiping other gods is spoken of as if the people were prostitutes. Alternate translation: “betrayed him by worshiping false gods”
contextId.quoteString: gave themselves like prostitutes to other gods and worshiped them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Israel wish to be like the sun that rises because no nation’s army is powerful enough to stop the sunrise.
contextId.quoteString: like the sun when it rises in its might

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Midianites are compared to a swarm of locusts because they came in with a great number of people and their livestock ate everything that grew.
contextId.quoteString: they would come as a swarm of locusts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “cloud” means a swarm. The author speaks of the army as if it were a swarm of locusts to emphasize how many soldiers there were.

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “terrible” means “frightening.” Alternate translation: “I was very afraid of him because he looked like an angel of God”

contextId.occurrenceNote: Samson easily broken the ropes that bound his hands. The author describes how easily he broke the ropes by saying it was as if they had become burnt flax. Alternate translation: “He snapped the ropes on his arms as easily as if they had been stalks of burned flax”
contextId.quoteString: The ropes on his arms became like burnt flax

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author describes how easily he broke the bowstrings by comparing them to how yarn breaks when it is burned. Alternate translation: “he broke the bowstrings as easily as if he were breaking burned yarn” or “he broke the bowstrings as easily as if they were made of thin yarn”

This refers to something that is strong. Alternate translation: “the strong thing”

Samson had seven locks of hair on his head. Locks are small bunches of hair. Here his locks of hair are described as “belonging” to his head. Alternate translation: “the seven locks of hair on his head”

The word “you” is plural and refers to the men of Ephraim. Jephthah is referring to the people of Gilead, including himself, when he says “me.” Alternate translation: “Why have you come to fight against us” (See also: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “you” is plural and refers to the guests at the feast.
